ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot about the ways political parties are integral to the American political system

I learned a lot about how different branches of government function and how they have changed over time. The focus was on parties specifically, and how their power or lack thereof influenced the political system. We also read a lot of different views from experts and professors on these subjects so it was interesting to learn about different theories in the topic.

This class was really interesting! I learned a lot about parties in Congress and how we think they function versus how they might actually function. Comparing various theories and ideas over time really helped put things in perspective as to how much parties have changed and how the past informs the present.
A better understanding of how political parties were formed in their American system. Also learned insight into how parties are run and maintained.
basic political science theories about parties like downs median voter theorem, duverger's law. nothing you haven't seen before
I gained a familiarity with modern and contemporary scholarship on the party system in the United States.
I learned a lot about political game theory and how politicians make decisions. It was a great class!
This class was great to gain a solid grasp about all of the theory, practice, and quirks of American parties, which I think is the most interesting aspect of politics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Topics are super interesting and well taught
Weaknesses: None that I can think of

I would say a strength is that it was very well organized and structured. The lectures were easy follow and slides were clear. A weakness is that the class could be a bit boring at times and it was easy to just write everything down on the slide and not pay as much attention.

I enjoyed the smaller class size but I think the section aspect could be improved by decreasing the amount of readings required by the teacher. Sometimes I felt overwhelmed by the amount of readings required.

strengths: pretty easy, nice professor, extra credit points for making predictions about election results
weaknesses: boring subject matter, section was essentially summarizing the readings one after the other instead of engaging in back and forth discussion, multiple choice sections on the tests were kind of weird/not well explained

This course is extremely well organized; each section seems to flow logically from the previous, and this makes it extremely easy to follow the progression of the three units of the course. However, there is entirely too much readingto the point that it genuinely precludes your capacity to understand the readings in depth. In my view, it's simply not possible to read everything if you want to understand the arguments actually being made. Instead, you have to focus on the core readings and ignore more tertiary topics.
A lot of reading, but the information was very important

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the course was low work but also very interesting. The sections had super good discussions as well. All around great class.

I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in political science and wants to gain a better understanding of the political system. If you aren't particularly interested in this topic I think it'd be hard to stay really invested in the class.
Yes! Definitely take it because it's a good class to add to your Political Science list and very applicable to politics today.
Yes. Great course for Political science majors.
if you really need an easy poli sci credit. but honestly you could do better

I would recommend this course to other political science majors seeking to develop a deeper understanding of the party systemspecifically as seen through orthodox views. If you are not interested in political parties, this course will not be very engaging.
Yes, it was great
100% Prof. Henderson is a great lecturer and the class size allowed a really solid learning experience in which I felt comfortable asking questions whenever I was confused.
Prof Henderson is an engaging lecturer, who covers the material in detail and is always keen on promoting class discussion.
